text: Every prime number is `2` or odd.
roundtrip-statement: This theorem states that a natural number \( p \) is prime if and only if it is either equal to 2 or odd.
prompt:
[{"role": "system",
  "content":
  "You are a Mathematics, Lean 4 and coding assistant who answers questions about Mathematics and Lean 4, gives hints while coding in Lean 4. You also translates from natural language to Lean Theorem Prover code and vice versa when asked. Follow EXACTLY any examples given when generating Lean code."},
 {"role": "user",
  "content":
  "Translate the following statement into Lean 4:\n## Theorem: This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, the remainder when `n` is divided by 2 is either 0 or 1. This is equivalent to saying that any natural number is either even (divisible by 2) or odd (leaves a remainder of 1 when divided by 2).\n\nGive ONLY the Lean code"},
 {"role": "assistant", "content": "‚àÄ (n : ‚Ñï), n % 2 = 0 ‚à® n % 2 = 1"},
 {"role": "user",
  "content":
  "Translate the following statement into Lean 4:\n## Theorem: This theorem states that for any natural number `p` which is prime, `p` gives a remainder of 1 when divided by 2 if and only if `p` is not equal to 2. In other words, a prime number `p` is odd (since it gives a remainder of 1 when divided by 2) if and only if it is not the number 2 (which is the only even prime number).\n\nGive ONLY the Lean code"},
 {"role": "assistant",
  "content": "‚àÄ {p : ‚Ñï} [inst : Fact p.Prime], p % 2 = 1 ‚Üî p ‚â† 2"},
 {"role": "user",
  "content":
  "Translate the following statement into Lean 4:\n## Theorem:  A prime number is odd if and only if it is not 2. (In other words, a prime number gives a remainder of 1 when divided by 2 if and only if it is not 2.)\n\nGive ONLY the Lean code"},
 {"role": "assistant",
  "content": "‚àÄ {p : ‚Ñï} [inst : Fact p.Prime], p % 2 = 1 ‚Üî p ‚â† 2"},
 {"role": "user",
  "content":
  "Translate the following statement into Lean 4:\n## Theorem:  For an odd prime number `p`, `2` is a square modulo `p` if and only if `p` is congruent to `1` or `7` modulo `8`.\n\nGive ONLY the Lean code"},
 {"role": "assistant",
  "content":
  "‚àÄ {p : ‚Ñï} [inst : Fact p.Prime], p ‚â† 2 ‚Üí (IsSquare 2 ‚Üî p % 8 = 1 ‚à® p % 8 = 7)"},
 {"role": "user",
  "content":
  "Translate the following statement into Lean 4:\n## Theorem: The only prime factor of prime `p` is `p` itself. \n\nGive ONLY the Lean code"},
 {"role": "assistant",
  "content": "‚àÄ {p q : ‚Ñï}, Nat.Prime p ‚Üí (Nat.factorization p) q ‚â† 0 ‚Üí p = q"},
 {"role": "user",
  "content":
  "Translate the following statement into Lean 4:\n## Theorem: `-2` is a square modulo an odd prime `p` iff `p` is congruent to `1` or `3` mod `8`. \n\nGive ONLY the Lean code"},
 {"role": "assistant",
  "content":
  "‚àÄ {p : ‚Ñï} [inst : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], p ‚â† 2 ‚Üí (IsSquare (-2) ‚Üî p % 8 = 1 ‚à® p % 8 = 3)"},
 {"role": "user",
  "content":
  "Translate the following statement into Lean 4:\n## Theorem: A prime natural number is prime in `‚Ñ§[i]` if and only if it is `3` mod `4` \n\nGive ONLY the Lean code"},
 {"role": "assistant",
  "content": "‚àÄ (p : ‚Ñï) [inst : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], Prime ‚Üëp ‚Üî p % 4 = 3"},
 {"role": "user",
  "content":
  "Translate the following statement into Lean 4:\n## Theorem: The only divisors of prime powers are prime powers. \n\nGive ONLY the Lean code"},
 {"role": "assistant",
  "content":
  "‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero Œ±] [dec_irr : (p : Associates Œ±) ‚Üí Decidable (Irreducible p)]\n  [inst_1 : UniqueFactorizationMonoid Œ±] [dec : DecidableEq Œ±] [dec' : DecidableEq (Associates Œ±)] {a p : Associates Œ±},\n  Irreducible p ‚Üí\n    ‚àÄ [inst_2 : (n : ‚Ñï) ‚Üí Decidable (a ‚à£ p ^ n)] {n : ‚Ñï} (h : a ‚à£ p ^ n),\n      a = p ^ Nat.find (_ : ‚àÉ n, (fun n => a ‚à£ p ^ n) n)"},
 {"role": "user",
  "content":
  "Translate the following statement into Lean 4:\n## Definition: The type of prime numbers \n\nGive ONLY the Lean code"},
 {"role": "assistant", "content": "Type"},
 {"role": "user",
  "content":
  "Translate the following statement into Lean 4:\n## Theorem: Every nonzero natural number has a unique prime factorization \n\nGive ONLY the Lean code"},
 {"role": "assistant", "content": "Set.InjOn Nat.factorization {x | x ‚â† 0}"},
 {"role": "user",
  "content":
  "Translate the following statement into Lean 4:\n## Theorem: The only numbers with empty prime factorization are `0` and `1` \n\nGive ONLY the Lean code"},
 {"role": "assistant",
  "content": "‚àÄ (n : ‚Ñï), Nat.factorization n = 0 ‚Üî n = 0 ‚à® n = 1"},
 {"role": "user",
  "content":
  "Translate the following statement into Lean 4:\n## Theorem: `2` is a square modulo an odd prime `p` iff `p` is congruent to `1` or `7` mod `8`. \n\nGive ONLY the Lean code"},
 {"role": "assistant",
  "content":
  "‚àÄ {p : ‚Ñï} [inst : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], p ‚â† 2 ‚Üí (IsSquare 2 ‚Üî p % 8 = 1 ‚à® p % 8 = 7)"},
 {"role": "user",
  "content":
  "Translate the following statement into Lean 4:\n## Theorem: A prime `p` satisfies `p % 2 = 1` if and only if `p ‚â† 2`. \n\nGive ONLY the Lean code"},
 {"role": "assistant",
  "content": "‚àÄ {p : ‚Ñï} [inst : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], p % 2 = 1 ‚Üî p ‚â† 2"},
 {"role": "user",
  "content":
  "Translate the following statement into Lean 4:\n## Theorem: `2` is not a factor of an odd natural number. \n\nGive ONLY the Lean code"},
 {"role": "assistant", "content": "‚àÄ {m n : ‚Ñï}, Odd n ‚Üí m ‚à£ n ‚Üí m ‚â† 2"},
 {"role": "user",
  "content":
  "Translate the following statement into Lean 4:\n## Theorem: Every prime number is `2` or odd.\n\nGive ONLY the Lean code"}]

text: There are infinitely many odd natural numbers.
roundtrip-statement: The theorem states that the set of odd numbers is infinite, meaning there is no largest odd number and there are infinitely many odd numbers.

text: If a vector space has dimension `2` then it is finite dimensional.
roundtrip-statement: This theorem states that for a division ring $K$, an additive commutative group $V$ that is a module over $K$, if the rank of $V$ as a $K$-module is 2, then $V$ is finite-dimensional over $K$.

theorem: (K : Type u) ‚Üí [inst : Field K] ‚Üí DivisionRing K
text: Every field is a division ring.
roundtrip-statement: This theorem states that for any type \( K \) equipped with the structure of a field, it also forms a division ring.

[{"role": "system",
  "content":
  "You are a Mathematics, Lean 4 and coding assistant who answers questions about Mathematics and Lean 4, gives hints while coding in Lean 4.  {"role": "user",
  "content":
